planet.description: This planet was not flagged as a potential planet candidate by the Kepler data pipeline. Citizen scientists discovered the transit simply by looking at many light curves by eye using the online tool at planethunters.org.

planet.name: KIC 6185331 b

planet.name: KIC 8435766 b
Kepler-78 b
2MASS 19345800+4426539 b
TYC 3147-188-1 b
planet.description: The Earth-sized planet KIC 8435766 b, also known as Kepler-78 b, was identified in the Kepler database and confirmed to be a transiting planet (as opposed to an eclipsing binary) through the absence of ellipsoidal or radial velocity variations. The planet has a dayside temperature of 2300K-3100K. The planet's density is similar to that of Earth, suggesting a composition of rock and iron.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of the Earth-sized planer Kepler-78 b.
Image credit: David A. Aguilar (CFA)

planet.name: KOI-1257 b
KOI-1257 01
KOI-1257.01
KIC8751933 b
planet.description: KOI-1257 b is a highly eccentric transiting exoplanet in an old, metal-rich binary system. The transits were initially spotted in the Kepler data. Follow-up observations consisting of a joint amateur and professional campaign confirmed the planetary nature of the transits.

planet.name: KOI-142 b
Kepler-88 b
planet.description: The planets in the KOI-142 have been confirmed using transit timing (TTV) and transit duration variations (TDV). The planets are just wide of the 2:1 mean motion resonance. It is often assumed that convergent migration locks planets in resonances. Then, multiple effects such as stochastic migration can move the planets slightly out of resonance. This is an important clue that might help scientists understand the formation of planetary systems. Note that the mass of the inner planet KOI-142 b is an upper limit.

This is an important clue that might help scientists understand the formation of planetary systems.

planet.name: KOI-314 b
Kepler-138 c
KOI-314 01
planet.description: This planet has been confirmed by researchers trying to find extrasolar moons. Although no exo-moon was detected, they were able to confirm the planetary nature of the transit signal by using transit timing variations (TTV). These variations are due to planets pulling on each other gravitationally, therefore extending or shrinking the time between transits. There is another planet candidate in the system which has not been confirmed yet.

planet.name: KOI-368 b
KOI-368.01
KOI-368 b
KOI-368 01
planet.description: The planet KOI-368 b was flagged by the Kepler team as a planet candidate. A new study by Zhou and Huang has now excluded blend scenarios and argues that the object has to be of substellar nature. The planet has a very high obliquity of 64 degrees. KOI-368 is the hottest host star to date for systems with spin-orbit measurements.

planet.name: KOI-55 b
planet.description: The planet KOI-55 b is orbiting a former red-giant star. It probably survived deep immersion in the red-giant's envelope. When the star ran out of hydrogen after about 10 billion years, it swelled dramatically. Our own sun will also undergo this phase and expand as far as the Earth's orbit. The planet that we see today in the KOI-55 system might just be the dense core of an evaporated giant planet which survived the death of its sun. The planet was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft but is not transiting. It is inferred from brightness pulsations.

planet.name: KOI-55 c
planet.description: The planet KOI-55 c is orbiting a former red-giant star. It probably survived deep immersion in the red-giant's envelope. When the star ran out of hydrogen after about 10 billion years, it swelled dramatically. Our own sun will also undergo this phase and expand as far as the Earth's orbit. The planet that we see today in the KOI-55 system might just be the dense core of an evaporated giant planet which survived the death of its sun. The planet was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft but is not transiting. It is inferred from brightness pulsations.

planet.name: KOI-680 b
planet.description: This planet was discovered with the Kepler telescope and confirmed with the SOPHIE spectrograph in France.

planet.name: KOI-806.01
Kepler-30 b
KIC 3832474 b
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-30 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis.

planet.name: KOI-806.02
Kepler-30 c
KIC 3832474 c
planet.description: This planet candidate was discovered with the Kepler spacecraft. Its host star gets periodically fainter whenever the planet is in front of the star. Because there are multiple phenomena that can create a signal that looks similar to a planetary transit, the candidates have to be confirmed with another method. For Kepler-30 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis.

For Kepler-30 the planetary nature of the companions has been confirmed by transit timing variations, caused by other planets in the system, and a stability analysis.

planet.name: LkCa 15 b
planet.description: The young (2 Myr) solar analog LkCa 15 shows evidence for a (proto)planet surrounded by dusty material. The object is located in a known gap in the transitional disk. More planets might be present in this system.

planet.name: Lupus-TR 3b
Lupus-TR 3 b
planet.description: Lupus-TR 3b is the only planet in the system. The planet is a typical a hot Jupiter orbiting Lupus-TR 3, an early dwarf type star

planet.name: Mars
Sun e
planet.description: Mars is named after the Roman god of war and often called the red planet.

planet.name: Mercury
Sun b
planet.description: Mercury is the innermost planet in the Solar System.

planet.name: MOA-2007-BLG-192-L b
MOA 2007-BLG-192L b
MOA-192 b
planet.description: The exoplanet MOA-2007-BLG-192-L b is orbiting a low mass brown dwarf, roughly 6% the mass of our Sun. This makes the primary too small to sustain fusion.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of the extrasolar planet MOA-2007-BLG-192-L b.
Credit: Joe Gallagher.

planet.name: MOA-2008-BLG-379L b
MOA 2008-BLG-379L b
planet.description: MOA-2008-BLG-379Lb is a planetary mass object discovered by gravitational microlensing. Because a faint source star crossed a large resonant caustic, the planetary signal dominates the light curve. A statistical model has been used to determine the physical system parameters.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-073L b
2MASS J18101138-2631226 b
planet.description: The planet MOA-2010-BLG-073L b was discovered by the Microlensing Observations in Astrophysics (MOA) survey. In a microlensing event like this, the light from a source star is bent and magnified by a foreground star and a planet. In this case the source star was previously known to be photometrically variable.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-328L b
planet.description: MOA-2010-BLG-328 is a planetary microlensing event. Multiple fits (including one with source orbital motion, xallarap) can explain the system. The mass of the companion might therefore change. However, all fits clearly show the presence of a planery mass object: MOA-2010-BLG-328L b.

planet.name: MOA-2010-BLG-477L b
MOA 2010-BLG-477L b
planet.description: Densely covered observations of a high-magnification event led to the discovery of the planet MOA-2010-BLG-477 b. Many different telescopes around the world have been used in this collaborative effort, including a 40cm telescope in Antartica.

planet.name: MOA-2011-BLG-293L b
planet.description: MOA-2011-BLG-293L b is a planet discovered by gravitational microlensing. Using follow-up observations on Keck, astronomers have identified the planet to lie in or near the habitable zone. It could in principle have habitable moons. It is also the first planet to be identified as being in the Galactic bulge with good confidence.

planet.name: MOA-2011-BLG-322 b
MOA 2011-BLG-322L b
HJD 2455773 b
planet.description: MOA-2011-BLG-322 b is a giant planet which was discovered by MOA, OGLE and the Wise Observatory. These observatories form a network and conduct a second generation microlensing survey. The survey aims to discover and characterize extrasolar planets and their frequency, by means of round-the-clock high-cadence monitoring of a large area of the Galactic bulge.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of the giant planet MOA-2011-BLG-322 b.
Image credit: Joe Gallagher

planet.name: MOA-2012-BLG-311 b
planet.description: This object was observed in a gravitational mirolensing event. A good mass estimate could not be obtained although the object is most likely of planetary nature. Unfortunately microlensing events are not repeatable and the planet is therefore marked as controversial.

planet.name: MOA-2013-BLG-220L b
planet.description: MOA-2013-BLG-220L is a microlensing event observed in 2013. The most likely candidate for the lens system is a planet orbiting a brown dwarf host star. Many of the parameters are uncertain and followup observations are required to further constrain the system. Observations will become possible in 2021 when the lens and source will have separated sufficiently to be resolved in high resolution images.

planet.name: MOA-bin-1 b
MOA-bin-1L b
planet.description: This planet has been discovered in data from the 2006-2007 MOA project by Bennett et al (2012). It is the first planetary event in which the stellar host is only detected through binary microlensing events. Note that the discovery paper has not been published in a peer-reviewed journal yet.

planet.name: mu Leo b
HD 85503 b
mu Leonis b
Rasalas b
Alshemali b
planet.description: The planet mu Leo b is orbiting the K giant mu Leonis, also known as Rasalas (the northern star of the lion's head). It was found using data from the Bohyunsan Observatory.

planet.name: Neptune
Sun i
Triton
planet.description: Neptune is the fourth largest planet in the Solar System.

planet.name: NN Ser (AB) c
NN Ser c
NN Serpentis (AB) c
planet.description: NN Ser AB is a short-period eclipsing binary. The system hosts a white dwarf, a red dwarf and two planets.

planet.name: NN Ser (AB) d
NN Ser d
NN Serpentis (AB) d
planet.description: NN Ser AB is a short-period eclipsing binary. The system hosts a white dwarf, a red dwarf and two planets.

planet.name: NSVS 14256825 c
planet.description: NSVS 14256825 is an HW Vir type binary which consists of a hot subdwarf and a main-sequence low-mass star in a close orbit.

planet.name: NSVS 14256825 d
planet.description: NSVS 14256825 is an HW Vir type binary which consists of a hot subdwarf and a main-sequence low-mass star in a close orbit.

planet.name: NY Virginis (AB) b
NY Vir (AB) b
NY Vir b
PG 1336-018 (AB) b
planet.description: The rapidly pulsating eclipsing binary NY Virginis has a period of 0.1 days. On a much longer timescale of 7.9 years, the system exhibits small amplitude cyclic variations which are associated with a third body in the system. A recent paper by Qian et. al. claims that this body is a giant circumbinary planet orbiting NY Vir at a distance of 3.3 astronomical units. There might be another planet in this system with an even longer orbital period, probably more than 15 years.

planet.name: OGLE-2008-BLG-092L b
planet.description: The planet OGLE-2008-BLG-092L b is a Uranus-mass planet in a binary stellar system. The discovery was made using the gravitational microlensing method. Some of the physical parameters of the system are not well constrained and model dependent.

planet.name: OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 b
OGLE 2011-BLG-251L b
planet.description: The planet OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 b was discovered using gravitational microlensing. The host star is an M dwarf. It is located towards the Galactic Bulge. The planet lies beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.
planet.imagedescription:
This plot shows the light curve of the OGLE-2011-BLG-0251 microlensing event. The main magnification is due to the host star, only the tiny perturbation near the peak is the signal caused by the planet.
Credit: Kains et al (2013).

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L b
OGLE 2012-BLG-026L b
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0026L c
OGLE 2012-BLG-026L c
planet.description: This multi-planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. Both planets are located beyond the snow-line, an important clue for planet formation models.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0358L b
OGLE 2012-BLG-358L b
planet.description: OGLE-2012-BLG-0358L b is a planetary mass object which is orbiting a brown dwarf. The discovery of this system suggests that planets can form around brown dwarf hosts, probably in a protoplanetary disk analogous to those around main sequence stars.

planet.name: OGLE-2012-BLG-0406L b
OGLE 2012-BLG-406L b
planet.description: This planetary system was discovered during a high-magnification gravitational microlensing event. It is the first microlensing planet found by analyzing data from only a single telescope. The planet is located beyond the snow-line. Some core accretion theories favor the formation of massive planets inside the snow-line. However, planetary migration in the protoplanetary disk might explain why the planet has moved outwards.

planet.name: OGLE-2013-BLG-0341L B b
OGLE-2013-BLG-0341LBb
planet.description: The planet OGLE-20130BLG-0341LB b was discovered with the gravitational microlensing method. The planet is orbiting a star with a very low luminosity. That is why even though the planet's semimajor axis is smaller than that of Earth, its temperature is well below freezing.

planet.name: omi CrB b
Omicron Coronae Borealis b
o CrB b
HD 136512 b
HR 5709 b
HIP 75049 b
planet.description: Discovered with precise Doppler measurements at Okayama Astrophysical Observatory.

planet.name: omi UMa b
Omicron Ursae Majoris b
Muscida b
o UMa b
HD 71369 b
HIP 41704 b
planet.description: Discovered with precise Doppler measurements at Okayama Astrophysical Observatory.

planet.name: Omicron Serpentis b
o Ser b
ome Ser b
o Serpentis b
HR 6581 b
HD 160613 b
HIP 86565 b
planet.description: The exoplanet Omicron Serpentis b is orbiting a star in the northern constellation Serpens. It was discovered using the radial velocity method. The measurements were taken at the Okaya Astrophysical Observatory.

planet.name: PH-1 A(ab) b
PH-1 b
KIC 4862625 A(ab) b
Planet Hunters 1 b
Kepler-64 b
Kepler-64 A(ab) b
planet.description: PH 1 b is a circumbinary planet in a quadruple star system. It is orbiting a double star and there is a second pair of stars at approximately 1000 AU. Citizen scientists discovered this planet by looking at many light curves using the online tool at planethunters.org.
planet.imagedescription:
An artist's conception of the planet in a four-star system.
Credit: Image by Haven Giguere/Yale.

planet.name: PH-2 b
KIC 12735740 b
2MASS 19190326+5157453 b
Planet Hunters 2 b
Kepler-86 b
planet.description: The exoplanet PH-2 b was discovered by citizen scientists using an online tool at planethunters.org. The planet is a gas giant and could be located in the star's habitable zone. The system might also have a faint binary companion.
planet.imagedescription:
Artistic rendition of a sunset view from the perspective of an imagined Earth-like moon orbiting the giant planet, PH2 b.
Image Credit: H. Giguere, M. Giguere/Yale University

planet.name: Pluto
Sun j
Charon
planet.description: Pluto is officially categorized as a minor planet by the International Astronomical Union.

planet.name: POTS-1 b
2MASS 13342613-6634520 b
planet.description: POTS-1 b is a Hot Jupiter and the first planet discovered by the pre-OmegaTranS project survey. This survey is looking at the Carina region of the Galactic disc with the European Southern Observatory Wide Field Imager at La Silla Observatory.

planet.name: Pr0201 b
BD+20 2184
2MASS J08414382+2013368
planet.description: This planet is a so-called Hot Jupiter which orbits tightly around its parent star in the Beehive Cluster, a collection of roughly 1,000 stars that appear to be swarming around a common center. The planet is not habitable but its sky would be starrier than what we see from Earth.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of a planet in the Beehive cluster.
Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: Pr0211 b
2MASS J08421149+1916373
planet.description: This planet is a so-called Hot Jupiter which orbits tightly around its parent star in the Beehive Cluster, a collection of roughly 1,000 stars that appear to be swarming around a common center. The planet is not habitable but its sky would be starrier than what we see from Earth.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of a planet in the Beehive cluster.
Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech

planet.name: PSO J318.5-22
PSO J318.5338-22.8603
2MASS J21140802-2251358
WISE J211408.13-225137.3
PSO J318-22
planet.description: PSO J318-22 is a free floating planetary mass object. It was discovered using the Pan-STARRS1 survey and is part of the beta Pictoris moving group. Evolutionary models give the object a temperature of 1160K and a mass about 6 times that of Jupiter, making PSO J318-22 one of the lowest mass free-floating objects in the solar neighborhood.

planet.name: PSR B1620-26 b
PSR B1620-26 (AB) b
planet.description: PSR B1620-26 b is a circum-binary planet. It is orbiting a pulsar and a white dwarf in the globular cluster M4. The cluster is estimated to be 12.2 billion years old.

planet.name: PSR J1719-1438 b
PSR 1719-14 b
planet.description: The 5.7ms pulsar PSR J1719-14 shows timing variations on a 2.17 hour timescale. These can be explained with a Jovian planet. However, because of the planet's short distance to the star, its density has to be more then 20 times that of Jupiter. The planet is most likely a remnant of a binary star which avoided complete destruction. The chemical composition, pressure and dimensions of the planet indicate that it is crystallized, or in other words, a very big diamond (Bailes et al 2011).

planet.name: Qatar-1 b
2MASS J20133160+6509433 b
GSC 04240-00470 b
planet.description: Qatar-1 b orbits a metal-rich K-dwarf, one of the faintest around which a planet has been discovered by ground based surveys. Measurements of the Rossiter-McLaughlin effect show that the sky-projected obliquity between the orbital plane of the planet and the star's rotation axis is only a few degrees.

planet.name: Qatar-2 b
GSC 04974-00112 b
2MASS J13503740-0648145 b
planet.description: Qatar-2b is a transiting hot Jupiter orbiting a K dwarf and was found by the Qatar Exoplanet Survey (QES). The radial velocity data shows evidence for a second companion with a period of about one year and a mass several times that of Jupiter.

planet.name: ROXs 12 b
planet.description: ROXs 12 b is a wide separation planetary mass companion to the star ROXs 12. The object was discovered over 10 years ago in a binary survey program, but follow-up observations only confirmed its planetary nature in 2013.

planet.name: ROXs 42 B b
ROXs 42 B (AB) b
planet.description: The substellar object ROXs 42B b is orbiting the binary M star ROXs 42B. It is most likely a planet and was discovered in 2013 by Thayne Currie.
planet.imagedescription:
This is the discovery image of ROX 42 B b.
Credit: Thayne Currie.

planet.name: RR Cae (AB) b
RR Cae b
RR Caeli b
planet.description: The binary RR Cae contains a cool white dwarf and an M-Type dwarf. Eclipse timing variations were used to find a circumbinary planet on an orbit nearly identical to that of Jupiter.

planet.name: SAND364 b
NGC 2682 SAND 364 b
BD+12 1917 b
planet.description: The host star of SAND364 b is located in the old open star cluster Messier 67 (M67). There are few galactic clusters which are older and none of those are as close as M67. The survey was conducted by European astronomers. They found that massive planets around stars of open clusters are as frequent as those around field stars.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's impression shows one of the three newly discovered planets in the star cluster Messier 67. In this cluster the stars are all about the same age and composition as the Sun. This makes it a perfect laboratory to study how many planets form in such a crowded environment. Very few planets in clusters are known and this one has the additional distinction of orbiting a solar twin - a star that is almost identical to the Sun in all respects.
Credit: ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: Saturn
Sun g
Dione
Enceladus
Iapetus
Rhea
Tethys
Titan
planet.description: Saturn is best known for its extensive ring system.

planet.name: tau Boo A b
Tau Booetis A b
HD 120136 A b
GJ 527 A b
Gliese 527 A b
tau Boo b
planet.description: The planet Tau Bootis b was one of the first exoplanets to be discovered back in 1996. In 2012, astronomers have detected the faint glow that is emitted from the planet, reliably probing the structure of the atmosphere of Tau Bootis b and deducing its mass accurately for the first time.
planet.imagedescription:
This artist's impression shows the exoplanet Tau Bootis b.
Credit: ESO/L. Calcada

planet.name: tau Ceti b
HD 10700 b
planet.description: Multiple periodic signals were found by Tuomi et al. in 2012 in the radial velocity data from HARPS, AAPS and HIRES. The planetary nature of the signals has yet to be confirmed.
planet.imagedescription:
Artist's impression of the Tau Ceti system
Picture credit: J. Pinfield for the RoPACS network at the University of Hertfordshire, 2012.

2MASS J19040985+3637574
TrES-1
planet.description: TrES-1 b orbits an orange dwarf star in the constellation of Lyra. It belongs to the class of Hot Jupiters

planet.name: TrES-2
TrES-2 b
Kepler-1 b
planet.description: The planet TrES-2 b is a Hot Jupiter orbiting the star GSC 03549-02811. Kipping and Spiegel (2011) identified it as the darkest known exoplanet, reflecting less than 1% of the light that hits it.

planet.name: TrES-3 b
2MASS J17520702+3732461
TrES-3
planet.description: The planet TrES-3 b has an orbital perdiod of just 31 hours and is undergoing orbital decay due to tidal effects.

planet.name: TrES-4 A b
TrES-4 b
TYC 2620-00648-1
2MASS J17531304+3712426
TrES-4
planet.description: The planet TrES-4 b was discovered by the Trans-Atlantic Exoplanet Survey and is located in the constellation Hercules. The host star is a member of a binary system.

planet.name: TrES-5 b
2MASS J20205324+5926556 b
TrES-5
planet.description: TrES-5 b transits one of the faintest stars with known transiting planets.

planet.name: Upsilon Andromedae A b
ups And A b
ups And b
planet.description: The binary star Upsilon Andromedae is only 40 light years away from Earth. The system hosts at least 4 jovian planets. It was the first multiple planet system to be discovered around a main sequence star.

ups And A c
ups And c

ups And A e

Sun h
Ariel
Miranda

Titania
Umbriel

planet.name: UScoCTIO 108 b
planet.imagedescription: This composite color image shows UScoCTIO 108 together with its companion. Credit: V.J.S. Bejar, Telescopio Nazionale Galileo, William Herschel Telescope.

planet.name: UZ For(ab) d
UZ For d
UZ Fornacis d
planet.description: UZ Fornacis is an eclipsing polar binary. High-speed photometry and archival eclipse timing data spanning 27 years suggest the presence of extrasolar planets (Potter et al 2011).

planet.name: Venus
Sun c
planet.description: Venus is the second planet from the Sun.

planet.name: WASP-100 b
1SWASP J043550.32-640137.3 b
2MASS 04355033-6401373 b
planet.description: This is a hot Jupiter discovered by the WASP team.

planet.name: WASP-101 b
1SWASP J063324.26-232910.2 b
2MASS 06332426-2329103 b
planet.description: This is a hot Jupiter discovered by the WASP team.

planet.name: WASP-103 b
planet.description: WASP-103 b is an ultra-short period jupiter sized planet at the edge of disruption.

planet.name: WASP-104 b
TYC 260-1073-1 b
planet.description: The transiting exoplanet WASP-104 b is just slightly larger than Jupiter. It was discovered by the WASP survey.

planet.name: WASP-106 b
TYC 4927-1063-1 b
planet.description: The transiting exoplanet WASP-106 b is just slightly larger than Jupiter. The orbital solution is consistent with zero eccentricity, which is interesting because many other similar planets are known to have eccentric orbits. The planet was discovered by the WASP survey.

planet.name: WASP-117 b
GSC08055-00876 b
planet.description: WASP-117b is a Hot Saturn on an eccentric and misaligned orbit. This is the first planet with a period beyond 10 days found by the WASP survey. Because of its large orbital separation tidal forces are weak and have had little impact on the evolution of the system.

planet.name: WASP-12 b
WASP-12 A b
2MASS J06303279+2940202 b
planet.description: The host star of WASP-12 b is the primary of a hierarchical triple system. The distant binary consists of two M dwarfs.

planet.name: WASP-2 A b
WASP-2 b
2MASS J20305413+0625463 b
planet.description: WASP-2 is an orange dwarf star that hosts the exoplanet WASP-2 b. It was discovered with the SuperWASP survey in 2006.

planet.name: WASP-20 b
CD-24 102 b
2MASS J00203853-2356086 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced in 2011 at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team. The scientific paper describing the discovery was published on the arXiv in 2014. The planet was discovered via the transit method and confirmed using radial velocity measurements.

planet.name: WASP-28 b
2MASS J23342787-0134482 b
planet.description: WASP-28b is an inflated Jupiter-mass planet on a 3.4 day orbit. The orbit is aligned with the sky projected spin axis of the star.

planet.name: WASP-42 b
planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: WASP-44 b
2MASS J00153675-1156172 b
planet.description: WASP-44 b is a sub-Jupiter mass planet in a 2.42 day orbit around a G8V star. It was discovered by the WASP collaboration and published in a paper by Anderson et al. (2012).

planet.name: WASP-45 b
TYC 6996-00583-1 b
2MASS J00205699-3559537 b
planet.description: WASP-45 b is a Jupiter mass planet transiting in front of the limb of its host star. Emission from Ca H+K suggests that the star is chromospherically active.

planet.name: WASP-46 b
2MASS J21145687-5552184 b
planet.description: WASP-46 b has about twice the mass of Jupiter and orbits a G6V star which shows evidence of being photospherically and chromospherically active.

planet.name: WASP-47 b

planet.name: WASP-50 b

planet.description: This planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team.

planet.name: WASP-70 A b
WASP-70 b
planet.description: WASP-70A b is part of a binary system. The planet has been announced at the Extreme Solar Systems II conference in Jackson Hole by the WASP team. It was published in a paper in October 2013.

planet.name: WASP-71 b
TYC 30-116-1 b
planet.description: WASP-71 b is a highly-irradiated planet which transits an evolved F8-type star every 2.9 days. The planet is larger than Jupiter but less dense.

planet.name: WASP-72 b
1SWASPJ024409.60-301008.5 b
planet.description: Despite its extreme irradiation, this planet has a size consistant with that of Jupiter. That makes it a possible outlier among the Hot Jupiters of similar masses, suggesting a significant enrichment in heavy elements.

planet.name: WASP-73 b
planet.description: The planet WASP-73 b has a high mean density. This suggests it is enriched in heavy elements.

planet.name: WASP-75 b
WASP-75
1SWASP J224932.56-104031.8 b
planet.description: WASP-75 b is a transiting Hot Jupiter. Its radius is slightly inflated as compared to theoretical planet models with no core.

planet.name: WASP-76 b
BD+01 316 b
1SWASP J014631.86+024202.0 b
2MASS 01463185+0242019 b
planet.description: This hot Jupiter has been discovered by the WASP transit survey and confirmed by radial velocity measurements. It is one of the most irradiated planets known. The host star is evolved and has a post main sequence radius.

planet.name: WASP-77 A b
1SWASP J022837.22-070338.4 b
planet.description: WASP-77 A b is a transiting Hot Jupiter (a planet similar to Jupiter but with an orbit much closer to the host star). It is orbiting a moderately bright G8 V star which is part of a visual binary. The binary has a separation of 3 arcseconds.

planet.name: WASP-78 b
2MASS J04150149-2206591 b
TYC 5889-271-1 b
GSC 05889-00271 b
planet.description: WASP-78b is a highly bloated Jupiter-mass exoplanet. It is orbiting an F-type star and was discovered and analyzed using WASP, TRAPPIST and CORALIE data. It is one of the hottest known exoplanets with an equilibrium temperature of 2350 degrees Kelvin.

planet.name: WASP-79 b
2MASS J04252901-3036016 b
TYC 7038-834-1 b
CD-30 1812 b
SAO 195000 b
GSC 7038-834 b
planet.description: WASP-79b is a highly bloated Jupiter-mass exoplanet. It is orbiting an F-type star and was discovered and analyzed using WASP, TRAPPIST and CORALIE data. WASP-79b is about twice as big as Jupiter, but its mass is smaller than that of Jupiter.

planet.name: WASP-80 b
2MASS J20124017-0208391 b
TYC 7038-834-1 b
BPM 80815 b
GSC 05165-00481 b
planet.description: WASP-80 b is a Jupiter-sized exoplanet but it has only half of Jupiter's mass. It has a transit depth of 3 percent, one of the largest reported so far.

2MASS 08442570+0151361 b
planet.description: WASP-84 b is a sub-Jupiter mass planet in an 8.5 day orbit. Of the transiting planets discovered from the ground, WASP-84 b has the third longest period.

planet.description: WASP-88 b is a Hot Jupiter discovered by the WASP transit survey. The planet joins a handful of planets with super-inflated radii.

planet.name: WTS-1 b
planet.description: The Hot Jupiter WTS-1 b is the first extrasolar planet found by the WFCAM Transit Survey. The observations were made at the 3.8-m United Kingdom Infrared Telescope and the Hobby-Eberly Telescope. The planet has one of the largest radius anomalies among the known Hot Jupiters its mass range.

planet.name: WTS-2 b
2MASS 19345587+3648557 b
SDSS J193455.87+364855.6 b
WISE J193455.86+364855.6 b
KIC 1173581 b
planet.description: WTS-2 b is an unusually close hot Jupiter on a 1.02-day orbit around a K2V star. The planet is close to the tidal destruction radius of the star and has a predicted remaining lifetime of only 40 million years.

planet.name: xi Aql b
Xi Aquilae b
ksi Aql b
HR7595 b
HD188310 b
HIP97938 b
planet.description: xi Aql is a giant star in the constellation of Aquila.

planet.name: XO-2S b
TYC 3413-210-1 b
planet.description: The planet XO-2S c is part of a multiplanetary system. The host star itself is part of a binary system. The other binary star, XO-2N also hosts a planet. This configuration makes the system a unique laboratory for understanding the diversity of planetary systems.

planet.name: XO-2S c
TYC 3413-210-1 c
planet.description: The planet XO-2S c is part of a multiplanetary system. The host star itself is part of a binary system. The other binary star, XO-2N also hosts a planet. This configuration makes the system a unique laboratory for understanding the diversity of planetary systems.

planet.name: YBP1194 b
planet.description: The star YBP1194 is one of the best solar twins identified so far. Its composition and age is very similar to that of our own Sun. It is located in the star cluster M67 and hosts a 0.34 Jupiter mass planet. The frequency of massive planets around stars of open clusters such as M67 turns out to be very similar to that of field stars.
planet.imagedescription:
This wide-field image of the sky around the old open star cluster Messier 67 was created from images forming part of the Digitized Sky Survey 2. The cluster appears as a rich grouping of stars at the centre of the picture. Messier 67 contains stars that are all about the same age, and have the same chemical composition, as the Sun.
Credit: ESO/Digitized Sky Survey 2 and Davide De Martin.

planet.name: YBP1514 b
NGC 2682 YBP 1514 b
planet.description: YBP1514 is a main sequence star in the open star cluster M67. It hosts a 0.4 Jupiter mass planet. The star cluster is between 3.2 and 5 billion years old and contains many stars with ages and compositions similar to that of our own Sun.
